title: Complex measure
text:
In <a href="mathematics">mathematics</a>, specifically <a href="measure%20theory">measure theory</a>, a complex measure generalizes the concept of <a href="measure%20%28mathematics%29">measure</a> by letting it have <a href="complex%20number">complex</a> values. In other words, one allows for <a href="Set%20%28mathematics%29">sets</a> whose size (length, area, volume) is a complex number.

Integration with respect to a complex measure.
One can define the "integral" of a complex-valued <a href="measurable%20function">measurable function</a> with respect to a complex measure in the same way as the <a href="Lebesgue%20integral">Lebesgue integral</a> of a <a href="Real%20number">real</a>-valued measurable function with respect to a <a href="Measure%20%28mathematics%29">non-negative measure</a>, by approximating a measurable function with <a href="simple%20function">simple function</a>s. Just as in the case of ordinary integration, this more general integral might fail to exist, or its value might be infinite (the <a href="Riemann%20sphere">complex infinity</a>).
Another approach is to not develop a theory of integration from scratch, but rather use the already available concept of integral of a real-valued function with respect to a non-negative measure. To that end, it is a quick check that the real and imaginary parts μ1 and μ2 of a complex measure μ are finite-valued <a href="signed%20measure">signed measure</a>s. The space of complex measures.
The sum of two complex measures is a complex measure, as is the product of a complex measure by a complex number. That is to say, the set of all complex measures on a measure space ("X", Σ) forms a <a href="vector%20space">vector space</a> over the complex numbers.
